Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: The Relationship between Diet Variability and Population Spread

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Modern humans originated in Africa during the Middle Stone Age (MSA) and during this time period developed complex foraging behaviors that facilitated their later migration out of Africa and across the world. Studying the full range of these early behaviors is critical to both understanding how modern humans adapted to diverse environments and refining models of human evolution and migration. The proposed research is based on materials excavated from a MSA archaeological site located in a previously unstudied region of the lowlands of northwestern Ethiopia along the Shinfa River, a major tributary to the Blue Nile River. The site is dated to greater than 50,000 years in age, close to the time when modern humans dispersed out of Africa. The research will study the fauna excavated at the site that includes a diverse array of terrestrial and aquatic animals that the humans hunted, trapped, collected, and brought back to the site to eat. Investigation of these animal remains will detail which species were collected, when they were collected, and how they were processed. The site is unusual for the MSA because in addition to terrestrial animals a large quantity of aquatic animals (e.g., fish, crocodile, and mollusk) are also present, and this combination of species permits an evaluation of the evidence for early riverine adaptations and structured seasonal resource use. Both of these activities have important implications for the evolution of modern human behavioral and social systems, and both have been argued to be largely absent during the MSA. Data from this study will also contribute to the broader debate about the significance of aquatic resource use during hominin evolution. Additionally, this project is the first to examine how regional seasonal extremes selected for flexible adaptive strategies in the MSA specifically within the context of temporary river ecosystems and how this particular ecological setting might have influenced early human behavior. The broader project involves a collaboration between US and Ethiopian scholars, students, officials, and local communities, and its NSF-supported research experience for undergraduates trains US and Ethiopian students and includes a focus on participants from groups underrepresented in the sciences.

Under the supervision of Dr. John Kappelman, Ph.D. candidate Christopher Davis will reconstruct foraging behavior at the archaeological site with a focus on answering two research questions: 1) Does the site document an early riverine adaptation? and 2) Does the site document structured seasonal occupation and resource exploitation? The methods are drawn from a large body of ethnoarchaeological and experimental research that uses faunal remains to reconstruct past human behavior. Faunal analyses will document the taxonomic groups and skeletal elements present at the site. Taphonomic analyses will identify the agent(s) of site formation, how the faunal elements were processed, and which natural processes potentially altered the assemblage. Behavioral analyses will reconstruct foraging strategies, and examine evidence for systematic riverine foraging and seasonal occupation. Comparative analyses will evaluate how foraging behaviors at this site compares with those from other similarly aged sites in Ethiopia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The origin of modern humans in Africa ~300,000 years ago is one of the most significant events in the history of Earth. Moreover, the expansion of our ancestors out of Africa and across the world beginning by at least 60-90,000 years ago is unparalleled in terms of the pace at which it occurred, the diversity of habitats populations began to occupy, and the far-reaching effects it continues to have on our planet and its inhabitants. The African Middle Stone Age (MSA: 320-45,000 years ago) includes the time interval for both events, and it was during this period that our ancestors developed complex behaviors that allowed them to survive and thrive in new and changing environments as they expanded both within and outside of Africa.

This project analyzes faunal remains from late MSA sites in the Horn of Africa, the time and place where models of human behavioral evolution and dispersal converge, in order to investigate foraging behavior and taphonomy at the primary site, SM1, and situate it within a broader regional context. SM1 is an open-air site located along the Shinfa River in northwestern Ethiopia, and contains a large number of terrestrial (e.g., antelope, pig, monkey, bird, snake) and aquatic fauna (e.g., fish, crocodile, mollusk), many of which were hunted, trapped, collected, and eaten by MSA humans. The intellectual merit of this project lies in analyzing the spatial context of the animal remains, identifying the species present, and documenting modifications to the bones. This information allows for a detailed understanding of which species the SM1 people ate, what time of year the animals were hunted and collected, how they were butchered, cooked, and consumed, and what natural processes affected the bones after they were deposited in the ground. The presence of both terrestrial and aquatic fauna also permits an opportunity to evaluate evidence for early riverine adaptations and structured seasonal resource use in the MSA, both of which have implications for the development of important aspects of modern human behavior and social systems.

Results document extensive evidence for human modification (e.g., cut and percussion marks, intensive burning) on both terrestrial fauna and fish bones at SM1. Taphonomic analyses indicate that carnivores also played a limited role in assemblage formation, and that natural processes (e.g., soil compaction, weathering, erosion) are responsible for a non-trivial amount of damage to the bones. Nonetheless, overall analyses clearly indicate that MSA humans were the primary agent of accumulation and modification for both terrestrial and aquatic animals at SM1, and that the taxonomic composition of the assemblage, spatial distribution of bones, and patterns of fragmentation and burning, are largely the product of human behavior.

These results also confirm that SM1 documents systematic riverine fishing and structured seasonal foraging in this region of the Horn of Africa during the time when humans began expanding out of Africa. This result is significant, because hypothesized dispersal routes typically pass through the Horn and follow rivers and/or coastlines out of Africa, so aquatic foraging adaptations would have been important for the survival of migrating groups. However, there is currently only one other inland site older than ~20,000 years ago where systematic riverine fishing and foraging is documented. Thus, this research provides valuable new insight into both MSA behavior in the Horn of Africa and the evolution of riverine adaptations more broadly, and has important implications for larger questions about human behavioral evolution and dispersal in the late Pleistocene. This research and other research in the Blue Nile Basin also suggest that, at least for groups living along temporary rivers, increasing aridity may have actually promoted and/or facilitated population movement during the late MSA. This idea is somewhat counterintuitive, and contrasts with the notion which underlies many current models of human dispersal out of Africa that large-scale migrations through northeastern Africa and Arabia were only possible during warmer, more humid periods when "green corridors" existed along river courses in these regions. However, ongoing work at SM1 and other sites in northwestern Ethiopia suggests that models of human behavioral evolution and dispersal in the late Pleistocene should give serious consideration to the possibility that population movements may also have occurred during more arid intervals. Additionally, this project expands the taphonomic baseline for future studies of open-air MSA sites in Africa because previous studies have focused largely on sites in South Africa, all but two of which are cave sites.

Studying the archaeological record of MSA human behavior is critical for understanding key aspects of human biological and behavioral evolution, and the successful worldwide dispersal of our species. Although previous work has provided valuable insight into MSA behavior, important questions remain that can only be addressed by studies of sites like this one in the Horn of Africa that sample new and diverse habitats and geographical regions.
